title: Maximum and Minimum Values of Quadratic Functions

content.explanation:
Every quadratic function has either a maximum or a minimum value, which occurs at the vertex of its parabola.

For a quadratic function f(x) = ax² + bx + c:
- If a > 0, the parabola opens upward and has a minimum value at the vertex
- If a < 0, the parabola opens downward and has a maximum value at the vertex

The value of the function at the vertex is the maximum or minimum value of the function.
content.example:
For f(x) = 2x² - 8x + 7:
- Since a = 2 > 0, the parabola opens upward and has a minimum value
- The vertex is at x = -b/(2a) = -(-8)/(2(2)) = 8/4 = 2
- The minimum value is f(2) = 2(2)² - 8(2) + 7 = 8 - 16 + 7 = -1
content.key_point: The sign of the leading coefficient 'a' tells us whether the quadratic function has a maximum (a < 0) or minimum (a > 0) value.

interactive.question: The function g(x) = -3x² + 12x - 8 has:
options: Neither a maximum nor a minimum value
